 a 'face' of a polyhedron is any of the polygons that make up its boundaries.
 For example, any of the squares that bound a cube is a face of the cube. The
 suffix -hedron is derived from the Greek word á¼Î´ÏÎ± (hedra) which means "face".

Sometimes, in the case of a pyramid, the term face is understood to
exclude the base.

The (two-dimensional) polygons that bound higher-dimensional polytopes are also
commonly called faces. Formally, however, a face is any of the lower dimensional
boundaries of the polytope, more specifically called an 'n-face'.
